text: the thing we like best about working
with AWS is the relationship we have is
a two-way thing so they bring solutions
to our problems
I'm Jonah Donovan I'm the CTO for the
Financial Times the Financial Times is
126 years old this year but it's very
much transformed itself into a digital
organization at the cutting edge of news
I look after the technology team
including the development and operations
teams we run the services for digital
and print we look after a number of
different areas of investment that the
FT has and we particularly focus on
being as embedded and as close to the
newsroom and the business as possible
the reasons we looked at AWS were fairly
straightforward the the cost model was
obviously important to us there are
things like global distribution said
does it have the capacity if you're a
global organization you care about
getting traffic everywhere you want you
want to be able to get to Asia as well
as you want to be able to get to London
and there was an element of the
relationship that we like how they've
supported us in making that transition
as a really key thing but for redshift
we were really interested in the speed
and the performance he gave us the
flexibility in the cost model so we're
not having to invest in something and
putting quite a lot of money into it
just to find out if it works which a lot
of the other bi products required us to
do the amount of time invested was
considerable just to test it out the
thing we really liked about the redshift
model is we're a very easy way to spin
it up try it out we were able to take
some data and compare it directly with
our existing service and from that we
could see very clearly that there were
huge benefits in moving forward the key
thing about the performance increase
we're seeing with redshift is around the
speed at which we can access the data
and use it some of the queries which
we've been running a running 98% faster
when the analyst started to do queries
they actually thought it was broken
because it was running so fast and
that's something which they're not very
used to they used to running the queries
and they'd got used to the idea of going
and making a cup of tea some of the
queries they ran ran in five or six
seconds and when they used to take
minutes so we can move to practically
real-time performance of queries we're
not running reports and making decisions
on a daily or weekly basis we can make
fast decisions we can do them when they
matter and the business
can show much more clearly where the
revenues coming from we can see what
people are liking on the side we can
start to look at how things might be
trending and we can correlate that with
other interesting information as well so
you start to layer up information in a
very powerful way which when you have
the performance to do it then that
becomes possible the amazing thing is
that not only are we seeing a huge
performance increase it's coming at an
80% reduction in costs from our previous
data warehouse with the same data size
footprint we can start to see how we can
get rid of some of our older
infrastructure how we can translate it
into a newer model it allows us to take
some of our existing platforms and look
at them in a different cost model which
for us is very powerful so for us that's
that's a win-win it's a great result to
have to have something that everyone
thinks is successful from top to bottom
in the business
